questions.question: Macroeconomists study
options: the decisions of individual households and firms.
the interaction between households and firms.
economy-wide phenomena.
regulations imposed on firms and unions.
questions.answer: economy-wide phenomena.

questions.question: Which of the following newspaper headlines is more closely related to what microeconomists study than to what macroeconomists study?
options: Unemployment rate rises from 5 percent to 5.5 percent.
Real GDP grows by 3.1 percent in the third quarter.
Retail sales at stores show large gains.
The price of oranges rises after an early frost.
questions.answer: The price of oranges rises after an early frost.

questions.question: Which of the following questions is more likely to be studied by a microeconomist than a macroeconomist?
options: Why do prices in general rise by more in some countries than in others?
Why do wages differ across industries?
Why do national production and income increase in some periods and not in others?
How rapidly is GDP currently increasing?
questions.answer: Why do wages differ across industries?

questions.question: Which of the following topics are more likely to be studied by a macroeconomist than by a microeconomist?
options: the effect of taxes on the prices of airline tickets, and the profitability of automobile-manufacturing firms
the price of beef, and wage differences between genders
how consumers maximize utility, and how prices are established in markets for agricultural products
the percentage of the labor force that is out of work, and differences in average income from country to country
questions.answer: the percentage of the labor force that is out of work, and differences in average income from country to country

questions.question: We would expect a macroeconomist, as opposed to a microeconomist, to be particularly interested in
options: explaining how economic changes affect prices of particular goods.
devising policies to deal with market failures such as externalities and market power.
devising policies to promote low inflation.
identifying those markets that are competitive and those that are not competitive.
questions.answer: devising policies to promote low inflation.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a question that macroeconomists address?
options: Why is average income high in some countries while it is low in others?
Why does the price of oil rise when war erupts in the Middle East?
Why do production and employment expand in some years and contract in others?
Why do prices rise rapidly in some periods of time while they are more stable in other periods?
questions.answer: Why does the price of oil rise when war erupts in the Middle East?

questions.question: The basic tools of supply and demand are
options: useful only in the analysis of economic behavior in individual markets.
useful in analyzing the overall economy, but not in analyzing individual markets.
central to microeconomic analysis, but seldom used in macroeconomic analysis.
central to macroeconomic analysis as well as to microeconomic analysis.
questions.answer: central to macroeconomic analysis as well as to microeconomic analysis.

questions.question: Which of the following statistics is usually regarded as the best single measure of a society's economic wellbeing?
options: the unemployment rate
the inflation rate
gross domestic product
the trade deficit
questions.answer: gross domestic product

questions.question: GDP
options: is used to monitor the performance of the overall economy but is not the single best measure of a society's economic well-being.
is used to monitor the performance of the overall economy and is the single best measure of a society's economic well-being.
is not used to monitor the performance of the overall economy but is the single best measure of a society's economic well-being.
is not used to monitor the performance of the overall economy and is not the single best measure of a society's economic well-being.
questions.answer: is used to monitor the performance of the overall economy and is the single best measure of a society's economic well-being.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about GDP is correct?
options: GDP measures two things at once: the total income of everyone in the economy and the unemployment rate of the economy's labor force.
Money continuously flows from households to government and then back to households, and GDP measures this flow of money.
GDP is to a nation's economy as household income is to a household.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: GDP is to a nation's economy as household income is to a household.

questions.question: In a simple circular-flow diagram, total income and total expenditure are
options: never equal because total income always exceeds total expenditure.
seldom equal because of the ongoing changes in an economy's unemployment rate.
equal only when the government purchases no goods or services.
always equal because every transaction has a buyer and a seller.
questions.answer: always equal because every transaction has a buyer and a seller.

questions.question: In a simple circular-flow diagram,
options: households spend all of their income.
all goods and services are bought by households.
expenditures flow through the markets for goods and services, while income flows through the markets for the factors of production.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.question: In a simple circular-flow diagram, firms use the money they get from a sale to
options: pay wages to workers.
pay rent to landlords.
pay profit to the firms' owners.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.question: In a simple circular-flow diagram, households buy goods and services with the income they get from
options: wages.
rents.
profits.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.question: In the actual economy, households
options: spend all of their income.
divide their income among spending, taxes, and saving.
buy all goods and services produced in the economy.
Both (a) and (c) are correct.
questions.answer: divide their income among spending, taxes, and saving.

questions.question: Total income from the domestic production of final goods and services equals
options: only household expenditures for these goods.
only household and business expenditures for these goods.
only household and government expenditures for these goods.
the expenditures for these goods whoever buys them.
questions.answer: the expenditures for these goods whoever buys them.

questions.question: In the actual economy, goods and services are purchased by
options: households, but not firms or the government.
households and firms, but not the government.
households and the government, but not firms.
households, firms, and the government.
questions.answer: households, firms, and the government.

questions.question: According to the circular-flow diagram GDP
options: can be computed as the total income paid by firms or as expenditures on final goods and services.
can be computed as the total income paid by firms, but not as expenditures on final goods and services.
can be computed as expenditures on final goods and services, but not as the total income paid by firms.
cannot be computed as either total income paid by firms or expenditures on final goods and services.
questions.answer: can be computed as the total income paid by firms or as expenditures on final goods and services.

questions.question: According to the circular-flow diagram GDP
options: can be computed as either the revenue firms receive from the sales of goods and services or the payments they make to factors of production.
can be computed as the revenue firms receive from the sales of goods and services but not as the payments they make to factors of production.
can be computed as payments firms make to factors of production but not as revenues they receive from the sales of goods and services.
cannot be computed as either the revenue firms receive or the payments they make to factors of production.
questions.answer: can be computed as either the revenue firms receive from the sales of goods and services or the payments they make to factors of production.

sector2.title: The Measurement Of Gross Domestic Product

questions.topic: The Measurement Of Gross Domestic Product
questions.question: GDP is defined as the
options: value of all goods and services produced within a country in a given period of time.
value of all goods and services produced by the citizens of a country, regardless of where they are living, in a given period of time.
value of all final goods and services produced within a country in a given period of time.
value of all final goods and services produced by the citizens of a country, regardless of where they are living, in a given period of time.
questions.answer: value of all final goods and services produced within a country in a given period of time.

questions.topic: The Measurement Of Gross Domestic Product
questions.question: Which of the following is a way to compute GDP?
options: add up the wages paid to all workers
add up the quantities of all final goods and services
add up the market values of all final goods and services
add up the difference between the market values of all final goods and services and then subtract the costs of producing those goods and services
questions.answer: add up the market values of all final goods and services

questions.topic: The Measurement Of Gross Domestic Product
questions.question: In order to include many different goods and services in an aggregate measure, GDP is computed using, primarily,
options: values of goods and services based on surveys of consumers.
market prices.
quantities purchased by a typical urban household.
profits from producing goods and services.
questions.answer: market prices.

questions.topic: The Measurement Of Gross Domestic Product
questions.question: Gross domestic product adds together many different kinds of goods and services into a single measure of the value of economic activity. To do this, GDP makes use of
options: market prices.
statistical estimates of the value of goods and services to consumers.
prices based on the assumption that producers make no profits.
the maximum amount consumers would be willing to pay.
questions.answer: market prices.

questions.topic: The Measurement Of Gross Domestic Product
questions.question: In computing GDP, market prices are used to value final goods and services because
options: market prices do not change much over time, so it is easy to make comparisons between years.
market prices reflect the values of goods and services.
market prices reflect the quantity sold.
None of the above is correct; market prices are not used in computing GDP.
questions.answer: market prices reflect the values of goods and services.

questions.topic: The Measurement Of Gross Domestic Product
questions.question: If the price of a Blu-Ray Disc player is three times the price of an MP3 player, then a Blue-Ray Disc player contributes
options: more than three times as much to GDP as does a MP3 player.
less than three times as much to GDP as does a MP3 player.
exactly three times as much to GDP as does a MP3 player.
None of the above is necessarily correct.
questions.answer: exactly three times as much to GDP as does a MP3 player.

questions.topic: The Measurement Of Gross Domestic Product
questions.question: Suppose that an economy produces 40,000 units of good A which sells at $4 a unit and 20,000 units of good B which sells at $5 per unit. Production of good A contributes
options: 2 times as much to GDP as the production of good B.
8/5 times as much to GDP as the production of good B.
5/4 times as much to GDP as the production of good B.
4/5 times as much to GDP as production of good B.
questions.answer: 8/5 times as much to GDP as the production of good B.

questions.topic: The Measurement Of Gross Domestic Product
questions.question: Suppose that an economy produces 30,000 units of good A which sells at $3 a unit and 60,000 units of good B which sells at $2 per unit. Production of good A contributes
options: 1/2 times as much to GDP as the production of good B.
3/2 times as much to GDP as the production of good B.
3/4 times as much to GDP as the production of good B.
4/3 times as much to GDP as production of good B.
questions.answer: 3/4 times as much to GDP as the production of good B.

questions.topic: The Measurement Of Gross Domestic Product
questions.question: Which of the following is included in GDP?
options: the market value of rental housing services, but not the market value of owner-occupied housing services.
the market value of owner-occupied housing services, but not the market value of rental housing services
both the market value of rental housing services and the market value of owner-occupied housing services
neither the market value of owner-occupied housing services nor the market value of rental housing services.
questions.answer: both the market value of rental housing services and the market value of owner-occupied housing services

questions.topic: The Measurement Of Gross Domestic Product
questions.question: The value of the housing services provided by the economy's owner-occupied houses is
options: included in GDP, and the estimated rental values of the houses are used to place a value on these housing services.
included in GDP, and the actual mortgage payments made on the houses are used to estimate the value of these rental services.
excluded from GDP since these services are not sold in any market.
excluded from GDP since the value of these housing services cannot be estimated with any degree of precision.
questions.answer: included in GDP, and the estimated rental values of the houses are used to place a value on these housing services.

questions.topic: The Measurement Of Gross Domestic Product
questions.question: Suppose an apartment complex converts to a condominium, so that the former renters are now owners of their housing units. Suppose further that a current estimate of the value of the condominium owners' housing services is the same as the rent they previously paid. What happens to GDP as a result of this conversion?
options: GDP necessarily increases.
GDP necessarily decreases.
GDP is unaffected because neither the rent nor the estimate of the value owner-occupied housing services is included in GDP.
GDP is unaffected because previously the rent payments were included in GDP and now the rent payments are replaced in GDP by the estimate of the value of owner occupied housing services.
questions.answer: GDP is unaffected because previously the rent payments were included in GDP and now the rent payments are replaced in GDP by the estimate of the value of owner occupied housing services.

questions.topic: The Measurement Of Gross Domestic Product
questions.question: James owns two houses. He rents one house to the Johnson family for $10,000 per year. He lives in the other house. If he were to rent the house in which he lives, he could earn $12,000 per year in rent. How much do the housing services provided by the two houses contribute to GDP?

questions.topic: The Measurement Of Gross Domestic Product
questions.question: Ryan lives in an apartment where he pays $7,000 a year in rent. Alexis lives in a house that could be rented for $14,000 a year. How much do these housing services contribute to GDP?

questions.topic: The Measurement Of Gross Domestic Product
questions.question: Most goods and services produced at home
options: and most goods and services produced illegally are included in GDP.
are included in GDP while most goods and services produced illegally are excluded from GDP.
are excluded from GDP while most goods and services produced illegally are included in

questions.question: GDP per person tells us the income and expenditure of the
options: richest person in the economy.
poorest person in the economy.
average person in the economy.
entire economy.
questions.answer: average person in the economy.

questions.question: GDP is used as the basic measure of a society's economic well-being. A better measure of the economic well-being of individuals in society is
options: saving per person.
GDP per person.
government expenditures per person.
investment per business firm.
questions.answer: GDP per person.

questions.question: Many things that society values, such as good health, high-quality education, enjoyable recreation opportunities, and desirable moral attributes of the population, are not measured as part of GDP. It follows that
options: GDP is not a useful measure of society's welfare.
GDP is still a useful measure of society's welfare because providing these other attributes is the responsibility of government.
GDP is still a useful measure of society's welfare because it measures a nation's ability to purchase the inputs that can be used to help produce the things that contribute to welfare.
GDP is still the best measure of society's welfare because these other values cannot actually be measured.
questions.answer: GDP is still a useful measure of society's welfare because it measures a nation's ability to purchase the inputs that can be used to help produce the things that contribute to welfare.

questions.question: GDP does not reflect
options: the value of leisure.
the value of goods and services produced at home.
the quality of the environment.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding GDP is correct?
options: GDP includes factory production, but not any harm that may be inflicted on the environment.
GDP accounts for all activities taking place outside markets.
GDP provides detailed information about the distribution of income.
GDP is a good measure of economic well-being for all purposes.
questions.answer: GDP includes factory production, but not any harm that may be inflicted on the environment.

questions.question: GDP is not a perfect measure of well-being; for example,
options: GDP incorporates a large number of non-market goods and services that are of little value to society.
GDP places too much emphasis on the value of leisure.
GDP fails to account for the quality of the environment.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: GDP fails to account for the quality of the environment.

questions.question: GDP is not a perfect measure of well-being; for example,
options: GDP excludes the value of volunteer work.
GDP does not address the distribution of income.
GDP does not address environmental quality.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.question: Suppose the government passes a law eliminating holidays and, as a result, the production of goods and services increases because people work more days per year (and thus enjoy less leisure per year). Based on this scenario, which of the following statements is correct?
options: GDP would definitely increase, despite the fact that GDP includes leisure.
GDP would definitely increase because GDP excludes leisure.
GDP could either increase or decrease because GDP includes leisure.
GDP could either increase or decrease because GDP excludes leisure.
questions.answer: GDP would definitely increase because GDP excludes leisure.

questions.question: Suppose the government eliminates all environmental regulations and, as a result, the production of goods and services increases, but there is considerably more pollution. Based on this scenario, which of the following statements is correct?
options: GDP would definitely increase, despite the fact that GDP includes environmental quality.
GDP would definitely decrease because GDP includes environmental quality.
GDP would definitely increase because GDP excludes environmental quality.
GDP could either increase or decrease because GDP excludes environmental quality.
questions.answer: GDP would definitely increase because GDP excludes environmental quality.

questions.question: Suppose that twenty-five years ago a country had nominal GDP of $1,000, a GDP deflator of 200, and a population of 100. Today it has nominal GDP of $3,000, a GDP deflator of 400, and population of 150. What happened to the real GDP per person?
options: It more than doubled.
It increased, but it less than doubled.
It was unchanged.
It decreased.
questions.answer: It was unchanged.

questions.question: GDP excludes most items that are produced and sold illegally and most items that are produced and consumed at home because
options: the quality of these items is not high enough to contribute value to GDP.
measuring them is so difficult.
the government wants to discourage the production and consumption of these items.
these items are not reported on income tax forms.
questions.answer: measuring them is so difficult.

questions.question: Estimates of the values of which of the following non-market goods or services are included in GDP?
options: the value of unpaid housework
the value of services provided by major household appliances purchased in a previous period
the estimated rental value of owner-occupied homes
All of the above are included in GDP.
questions.answer: the estimated rental value of owner-occupied homes

questions.question: Over the last few decades, Americans have chosen to cook less at home and eat more at restaurants. This change in behavior, by itself, has
options: reduced measured GDP.
not affected measured GDP.
increased measured GDP by the value of the restaurant meals.
increased measured GDP by the value added by the restaurant's preparation and serving of the meals.
questions.answer: increased measured GDP by the value added by the restaurant's preparation and serving of the meals.

questions.question: Over time, people have come to rely more on market-produced goods and services and less on goods and services they produce for themselves. For example, busy people with high incomes, rather than cleaning their own houses, hire people to clean their houses. By itself, this change has
options: caused measured GDP to fall.
not caused any change in measured GDP.
caused measured GDP to rise.
probably changed measured GDP, but in an uncertain direction; the direction of the change depends on the difference in the quality of the cleaning that has resulted.
questions.answer: caused measured GDP to rise.

questions.question: Ralph pays someone to mow his lawn, while Mike mows his own lawn. Regarding these two practices, which of the following statements is correct?
options: Only Ralph's payments are included in GDP.
Ralph's payments as well as the estimated value of Mike's mowing services are included in GDP.
Neither Ralph's payments nor the estimated value of Mike's mowing services is included in GDP.
Ralph's payments are included in GDP, while the estimated value of Mike's mowing services is included in GDP only if Mike voluntarily provides his estimate of that value to the government.
questions.answer: Only Ralph's payments are included in GDP.

questions.question: Susan switches from going to Speedy Lube for an oil change to changing the oil in her car herself. Which of the following is correct? The value of changing the oil is
options: included in GDP whether Susan pays Speedy Lube to change it or changes it herself.
included in GDP if Susan pays Speedy Lube to change it but not if she changes it herself.
included in GDP if Susan changes it herself, but not if she pays Speedy Lube to change it.
not included in GDP whether Susan pays Speedy lube to change it or she changes it herself.
questions.answer: included in GDP if Susan pays Speedy Lube to change it but not if she changes it herself.

questions.question: Rachel babysits for her sister for no pay. When she babysits for someone else she charges $8 an hour. When is Rachel's babysitting included in GDP?
options: When she babysits for her sister and when she babysits for someone else.
When she babysits for her sister, but not when she babysits for someone else.
When she babysits for someone else, but not when she babysits for her sister.
Neither when she babysits for her sister nor for someone else.
questions.answer: When she babysits for someone else, but not when she babysits for her sister.

questions.question: Which of the following is not included in GDP?
options: carrots grown in your garden and eaten by your family
carrots purchased at a farmer's market and eaten by your family
carrots purchased at a grocery store and eaten by your family
None of the above are included in GDP.
questions.answer: carrots grown in your garden and eaten by your family

questions.question: A professional gambler moves from a state where gambling is illegal to a state where gambling is legal. Most of his income was, and continues to be, from gambling. His move
options: raises GDP.
decreases GDP.
doesn't change GDP because gambling is never included in GDP.
doesn't change GDP because in either case his income is included.
questions.answer: raises GDP.

questions.question: If a state made a previously-illegal activity, such as gambling or prostitution, legal, then, other things equal, GDP
options: decreases.
increases.
doesn't change because both legal and illegal production are included in GDP.
doesn't change because these activities are never included in GDP.
questions.answer: increases.

questions.question: Which of the following is included in GDP?
options: medical marijuana purchased from a government-run pharmacy by a glaucoma patient
recreational marijuana purchased from a drug dealer by a college student
recreational marijuana produced and consumed by a man in his attic
All of the above are included in GDP.
questions.answer: medical marijuana purchased from a government-run pharmacy by a glaucoma patient

questions.question: Darin grows and sells marijuana to Jennifer. Thomas is an organic farmer who sells broccoli to Jennifer. Marijuana is an illegal good and broccoli is a legal good. Assume that if Jennifer marries either, they give her what they use to sell her. Which of the following statements is consistent with the way GDP is computed?
options: GDP will fall if Jennifer marries either Darin or Thomas..
GDP will fall if Jennifer marries Darin but not if she marries Thomas.
GDP will fall if Jennifer marries Thomas but not if she marries Darin.
GDP remains the same whether Jennifer marries Darin or Thomas.
questions.answer: GDP will fall if Jennifer marries Thomas but not if she marries Darin.

questions.question: Spots, Inc. produces ink and sells it to Write on Target, which makes pens. The ink produced by Spots, Inc. is called
options: an inventory good.
a transitory good.
a final good.
an intermediate good.
questions.answer: an intermediate good.

questions.question: The purchase of rice produced this period is included in GDP if the rice is
options: used in a meal a restaurant sells during the same period they buy the rice.
purchased by a family who uses it to make tuna casserole for its supper.
purchased by a frozen food company to increase its inventory.
B and C are correct.
questions.answer: B and C are correct.

questions.question: A farmer sells $50,000 of apples to individuals who take them home to eat and $75,000 of apples to a company that uses them all to produce cider. How much of the farmer's sales will be included as apples in GDP?

Sam, an American citizen, prepares meals for his family at home. Ellen, a Canadian citizen, commutes to the U.S. to help prepare meals at a restaurant in Idaho. Whose value of services preparing meals is included in U.S. GDP?
options: Sam's and Ellen's.
Sam's but not Ellen's.
Ellen's but not Sam's.
Nether Sam's nor Ellen's.
questions.answer: Ellen's but not Sam's.

questions.question: Grapes are considered intermediate goods
options: whether the purchaser uses them to make wine to sell or eats them.
if the purchaser uses them to make wine to sell others but not if the purchaser eats them.
if the purchaser eats them, but not if the purchaser uses to them to make wine to sell.
None of the above is correct.
questions.answer: if the purchaser uses them to make wine to sell others but not if the purchaser eats them.

questions.question: Gasoline is considered a final good if it is sold by a
options: gasoline station to a bus company that operates a bus route between San Francisco and Los Angeles.
pipeline operator to a gasoline station in San Francisco.
gasoline station to a motorist in Los Angeles.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: gasoline station to a motorist in Los Angeles.

questions.question: A steel company sells some steel to a bicycle company for $150. The bicycle company uses the steel to produce a bicycle, which it sells for $250. Taken together, these two transactions contribute
options: $150 to GDP.
$250 to GDP.
between $250 and $400 to GDP, depending on the profit earned by the bicycle company when it sold the bicycle.
$400 to GDP.
questions.answer: $250 to GDP.

questions.question: Al's Aluminum Company sells $1 million worth of aluminum to Shiny Foil Company, which uses the aluminum to make aluminum foil. Shiny Foil Company sells $4 million worth of aluminum foil to households. The transactions just described contribute how much to GDP?
options: $1 million
$3 million
$4 million
$5 million
questions.answer: $4 million

questions.question: One bag of flour is sold for $1.00 to a bakery, which uses the flour to bake bread that is sold for $3.00 to consumers. A second bag of flour is sold for $1 to a grocery store who sells it to a consumer for $2.00. Taking these four transactions into account, what is the effect on GDP?
options: GDP increases by $3.00.
GDP increases by $5.00.
GDP increases by $6.00.
GDP increases by $7.00.
questions.answer: GDP increases by $5.00.

questions.question: One bag of oranges is sold for $6.00 to a company that turns them into juice which is sold to consumers for $12.00. Another bag of oranges is purchased by a grocery store for $6.00 who then sells it to a consumer for $7. Taking these four transactions into account, how much is added to GDP?
options: None of the above is correct.

questions.question: A painter pays $500 for paint he uses to repaint a house. He then presents a bill for $1200 that covers his time and expenses to the homeowner. How much do these transactions add to GDP?
Bountiful Harvest Bakery buys $4.00 of flour from Grinkers' Mill and uses the flour to make bread sold to the public for $12.00. Taking these two transactions into account, what is the effect on GDP?
options: GDP increases by $4.00
GDP increases by $8.00
GDP increases by $12.00
GDP increases by $16.00
questions.answer: GDP increases by $12.00

questions.question: Janet bought flour and used it to bake bread she ate. ABC Bakery bought flour which it used to bake bread that customers purchased. In which case will the flour be counted as a final good?
options: Janet's purchase and ABC Bakery's purchase.
ABC Bakery's purchase but not Janet's purchase.
Janet's purchase but not ABC Bakery's purchase.
Neither Janet's purchase nor ABC Bakery's purchase.
questions.answer: Janet's purchase but not ABC Bakery's purchase.

questions.question: Tim mows the yard for his neighbors. He spends $1 on gas and charges them $20 for each lawn he mows. What's the total contribution to GDP each time Tim mows a yard?

Suppose there are only two firms in an economy: Cowhide, Inc. produces leather and sells it to Couches, Inc., which produces and sells leather furniture. With each $1,000 of leather that it buys from Cowhide, Inc., Couches, Inc. produces a couch and sells it for $3,000. Neither firm had any inventory at the beginning of 2009. During that year, Cowhide produced enough leather for 20 couches. Couches, Inc. bought 80% of that leather for $16,000 and promised to buy the remaining 20% for $4,000 in 2010. Couches, Inc. produced 16 couches during 2009 and sold each one during that year for $3,000. What was the economy's GDP for 2009?

Suppose there are only two firms in an economy: Rolling Rawhide produces rawhide and sells it to Chewy Chomp, Inc., which uses the rawhide to produce and sell dog chews. With each $2 of rawhide that it buys from Rolling Rawhide, Chewy Chomp, Inc. produces a dog chew and sells it for $5. Neither firm had any inventory at the beginning of 2008. During that year, Rolling Rawhide produced enough rawhide for 1000 dog chews. Chewy Chomp, Inc. bought 75% of that rawhide for $1500 and promised to buy the remaining 25% for $500 in 2009. Chewy Chomp, Inc. produced 750 dog chews during 2008 and sold each one during that year for $5. What was the economy's GDP for 2008?

In 2009, Corny Company grows and sells $2 million worth of corn to Tasty Cereal Company, which makes corn flakes. Tasty Cereal Company produces $6 million worth of corn flakes in 2009, with sales to households during the year of $4.5 million. The unsold $1.5 million worth of corn flakes remains in Tasty Cereal Company's inventory at the end of 2009. The transactions just described contribute how much to GDP for 2009?
options: $4.5 million
$6 million
$6.5 million
$8 million
questions.answer: $6 million

questions.question: Whip-It manufactures blenders. In 2009 it had $50,000 of blenders in inventory. In 2010 it sold $300,000 of blenders to consumers and had $40,000 of blenders in inventory. How much did blenders produced by Whip-it add to GDP in 2010?
A newspaper article informs you that most businesses reduced production in the last quarter but also sold from their inventories during the last quarter. Based on this information GDP likely
options: increased.
decreased.
stayed the same.
may have increased, decreased, or stayed the same.
questions.answer: decreased.

questions.question: Which of the following domestically produced items is not included in GDP?
options: a bottle of shampoo
a hairdryer
a haircut
All of the above are included in GDP.
questions.answer: All of the above are included in GDP.

questions.question: Which of the following is not included in GDP?
options: a can of bug spray
the services of an exterminator
the honey produced and sold by a beekeeper
All of the above are included in GDP.
questions.answer: All of the above are included in GDP.

questions.question: Gross domestic product includes all
options: legal and illegal final goods, but it excludes all legal and illegal final services.
legal and illegal final goods and all legal and illegal final services.
legal final goods and services, but it excludes illegal final goods and services.
legal and illegal final goods and legal final services, but it excludes illegal final services.
questions.answer: legal final goods and services, but it excludes illegal final goods and services.

questions.question: Transactions involving items produced in the past, such as the sale of a 5-year-old automobile by a used car dealership or the purchase of an antique rocking chair by a person at a yard sale, are
options: included in current GDP because GDP measures the value of all goods and services sold in the current year.
included in current GDP but valued at their original prices.
not included in current GDP because it is difficult to determine their value.
not included in current GDP because GDP only measures the value of goods and services produced in the current year.
questions.answer: not included in current GDP because GDP only measures the value of goods and services produced in the current year.

questions.question: Which of the following transactions would be included in GDP for 2010?
options: In February 2010, Amanda sells a 1996 Honda Accord to Isabella.
In February 2010, Amanda buys a ticket to visit a zoo in Florida. She visits the zoo in April 2011.
In December 2010, Isabella eats onions that she harvested from her backyard garden in October 2010.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: In February 2010, Amanda buys a ticket to visit a zoo in Florida. She visits the zoo in April 2011.

questions.question: George lived in a home that was newly constructed in 2005 for which he paid $200,000. In 2008 he sold the house for $225,000. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the sale of the house?
options: The 2008 sale increased 2008 GDP by $225,000 and had no effect on 2005 GDP.
The 2008 sale increased 2008 GDP by $25,000 and had no effect on 2005 GDP.
The 2008 sale increased 2008 GDP by $225,000; furthermore, the 2008 sale caused 2005 GDP to be revised upward by $25,000.
The 2008 sale affected neither 2008 GDP nor 2005 GDP.
questions.answer: The 2008 sale affected neither 2008 GDP nor 2005 GDP.

questions.question: The Patersons bought a home that was newly constructed in 2007 for $275,000. They sold the home in 2009 for $205,000. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the sale of the house?
options: The 2009 sale increased 2009 GDP by $205,000 and had no effect on 2007 GDP.
The 2009 sale reduced 2009 GDP by $70,000 and had no effect on 2007 GDP.
The 2009 sale increased 2009 GDP by $205,000; and caused 2007 GDP to be revised downward by $70,000.
The 2009 sale affected neither 2007 GDP nor 2009 GDP.
questions.answer: The 2009 sale affected neither 2007 GDP nor 2009 GDP.

questions.question: In early2010 Molly paid $200,000 for a house built in 2000. She spent $30,000 on new materials to remodel the house. Although Molly lived in the house after she remodeled it, its rental value rose. Which of the following contributed to real GDP in 2010?
options: the price of the house, the cost of remodeling materials, the increase in rental value
the price of the house and the cost of remodeling materials, but not the increase in rental value
the costs of the remodeling materials and the increase in rent, but not the price of the house
None of the above are correct.
questions.answer: the costs of the remodeling materials and the increase in rent, but not the price of the house

questions.question: Tom and Lilly rented a house for $12,000 last year. At the start of the year they bought the house they had been renting directly from the owner for $250,000. They believe they could rent it for $12,000 this year, but stay in the house. How much does Tom and Lilly's decision to buy the house change GDP?
options: it reduces GDP by $12,000
it does not change GDP
it raises GDP by $238,000
it raises GDP by $250,000
questions.answer: it does not change GDP

questions.question: Sally purchases a classic 1964 car she saw for sale on someone's lawn. She then purchases some new parts and spends 120 hours refurbishing the car which she keeps. Which of the following is included in GDP?
options: the amount she paid to buy the car
the amount she paid to buy new parts
the value of her time repairing the car
All of the above are included.
questions.answer: the amount she paid to buy new parts

questions.question: Tyler and Camille both live in Oklahoma. A new-car dealer in Oklahoma bought a new car from the manufacturer for $18,000 and sold it to Tyler for $22,000. Later that year, Tyler sold the car to Camille for $17,000. By how much did these transactions contribute to U.S. GDP for the year?

Consider two cars manufactured by Chevrolet in 2009. During 2009, Chevrolet sells one of the two cars to Sean for $24,000. Later in the same year, Sean sells the car to Kati for $19,000. The second automobile, with a market value of $30,000, is unsold at the end of 2010 and it remains in Chevrolet's inventory. The transactions just described contribute how much to GDP for 2009?

JR sells RV's. In 2010 she added $400,000 to her inventory. $100,000 of this addition was from used RV's she purchased while the remaining $300,000 was from her purchases of newly manufactured RV's. How much of JR's inventory is included in 2010 GDP?
Which of the following is included in U.S. GDP?
options: the value of production by a Singaporean working in the U.S.
the value of production by an American working in Singapore
Both (a) and (b) are correct.
Neither (a) nor (b) is correct.
questions.answer: the value of production by a Singaporean working in the U.S.

questions.question: Sheri, a U.S. citizen, works only in Germany. The value she adds to production in Germany is included
options: in both German GDP and U.S. GDP.
in German GDP, but is not included in U.S. GDP.
in U.S. GDP, but is not included in German GDP.
in neither German GDP nor U.S. GDP.
questions.answer: in German GDP, but is not included in U.S. GDP.

questions.question: Martin, a U.S. citizen, travels to Mexico and buys a newly manufactured motorcycle made there. His purchase is included in
options: both Mexican GDP and U.S. GDP.
Mexican GDP, but it is not included in U.S. GDP.
U.S. GDP, but it is not included in Mexican GDP.
neither Mexican GDP nor U.S. GDP.
questions.answer: Mexican GDP, but it is not included in U.S. GDP.

questions.question: An American company operates a fast food restaurant in Paris, France. Which of the following statements is accurate?
options: The value of the goods and services produced by the restaurant is included in both French GDP and U.S. GDP.
The value added by American workers and equipment in France is included in U.S. GDP and the value added by French workers and equipment is added to French GDP.
The value of the goods and services produced by the restaurant is included in French GDP, but not in U.S. GDP.
The value of the goods and services produced by the restaurant is included in U.S. GDP, but not in French GDP.
questions.answer: The value of the goods and services produced by the restaurant is included in French GDP, but not in U.S. GDP.

questions.question: Michigan Tea Company sold $15 million worth of tea it produced. In producing this tea it purchased $5 million dollars worth of ingredients from foreign countries and paid workers who reside in Canada but commute to the U.S. $1 million. How much did these transactions add to U.S. GDP?
options: $21 million
$15 million
$10 million
$9 million
questions.answer: $10 million

questions.question: Quality Motors is a Japanese-owned company that produces automobiles; all of its automobiles are produced in American plants. In 2010 Quality Motors produced $30 million worth of automobiles, with $17 million in sales to Americans, $9 million in sales to Canadians, and $4 million worth of automobiles added to Quality Motors' inventory. The transactions just described contribute how much to U.S. GDP for 2010?
options: $17 million
$21 million
$26 million
$30 million
questions.answer: $30 million

questions.question: Quality Motors is a Japanese-owned company that produces automobiles; all of its automobiles are produced in American plants. In 2008, Quality Motors produced $25 million worth of automobiles and sold $12 million in the U.S. and $13 million in Mexico. In addition, it sold $2 million from the previous year's inventory in the U.S. The transactions just described contribute how much to U.S. GDP for 2008?
options: $12 million
$14 million
$25 million
$27 million
questions.answer: $25 million

questions.question: Which of the following items is included in U.S. GDP?
options: goods produced by foreign citizens working in the United States
the difference in the price of the sale of an existing home and its original purchase price
known illegal activities
None of the above is included in U.S. GDP.
questions.answer: goods produced by foreign citizens working in the United States

questions.question: Which of the following items is included in U.S. GDP?
options: final goods and services that are purchased by the U.S. federal government
intermediate goods that are produced in the U.S. but that are unsold at the end of the GDP accounting period
goods and services produced by foreign citizens working in the U.S.
All of the above are included in U.S. GDP.
questions.answer: All of the above are included in U.S. GDP.

questions.question: Which of the following items is included in U.S. GDP?
options: the estimated value of production accomplished at home, such as backyard production of fruits and vegetables
the value of illegally-produced goods and services
the value of cars and trucks produced in foreign countries and sold in the U.S.
None of the above is included in U.S. GDP.
questions.answer: None of the above is included in U.S. GDP.

questions.question: Which of the following is not included in U.S. GDP?
options: unpaid cleaning and maintenance of houses
services such as those provided by lawyers and hair stylists
the estimated rental value of owner-occupied housing
production of foreign citizens living in the United States
questions.answer: unpaid cleaning and maintenance of houses

questions.question: Which of the following is not included in U.S. GDP?
options: additions of newly produced output to inventory
production of U.S citizens working in foreign countries.
the estimated rental value of owner-occupied housing
the value of food purchased from a grocery store to make meals at home without pay
questions.answer: production of U.S citizens working in foreign countries.

questions.question: Which of the following values would be included in U.S. GDP for 2009?
options: the rent that Sean, an American citizen, would have paid on his home in New York in 2009 had he not owned that home
the rent that John, an American citizen, paid on his apartment in San Francisco in 2009
the value of the legal services provided by Juan, an attorney and a Mexican citizen, who lived in Houston and practiced law there in 2009
All of the above would be included in U.S. GDP for 2009.
questions.answer: All of the above would be included in U.S. GDP for 2009.

questions.question: Which of the following examples of production of goods and services would be included in U.S. GDP?
options: Samantha, a Canadian citizen, grows sweet corn in Minnesota and sells it to a grocery store in Canada.
Ian, an American citizen, grows peaches for his family in the back yard of their Atlanta home.
Leo, an American citizen, grows marijuana in his Seattle home and sells it to his friends and neighbors.
None of the above examples of production would be included in U.S. GDP.
questions.answer: Samantha, a Canadian citizen, grows sweet corn in Minnesota and sells it to a grocery store in Canada.

questions.question: Which of the following transactions adds to U.S. GDP for 2010?
options: In 2010, Ashley sells a car that she bought in 2006 to William for $5,000.
An American management consultant works in Mexico during the summer of 2010 and earns the equivalent of $30,000 during that time.

When John and Jennifer were both single, they lived in separate apartments and each paid $750 in rent. John and Jennifer got married in 2010 and they bought a previously unoccupied house that, according to reliable estimates, could be rented for $1,600 per month.
None of the above transactions adds to U.S. GDP for 2010.
questions.answer: When John and Jennifer were both single, they lived in separate apartments and each paid $750 in rent. John and Jennifer got married in 2010 and they bought a previously unoccupied house that, according to reliable estimates, could be rented for $1,600 per month.

questions.question: Which of the following transactions adds to U.S. GDP for 2010?
options: In 2010, Marvin Windows manufactures 20 windows that will eventually be installed in an office building in Minneapolis. The windows remain in Marvin's inventory at the end of

questions.question: The government of a country, which has adopted American GDP accounting conventions, reported that seasonally adjusted GDP in quarter 3 was $12 billion at an annual rate. This means that the seasonally-adjusted market value of all final goods and services produced within this country in quarter 3 was
options: $3 billion.
$4 billion.
$12 billion.
$48 billion.
questions.answer: $3 billion.

options: An Irish marketing consultant works in Boston during the summer of 2010 and earns $50,000 during that time.

When Tim and Tina were both single, they lived in separate apartments and each paid $750 in rent. Tim and Tina got married in 2010 and they bought a previously unoccupied house that, according to reliable estimates, could be rented for $1,550 per month.
All of the above transactions add to U.S. GDP for 2006.
questions.answer: All of the above transactions add to U.S. GDP for 2006.

questions.question: In the equation Y = C + I + G + NX,
options: Y represents the economy's total expenditure.
C represents household expenditures on services and durable goods.
all of the variables are always positive numbers.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: Y represents the economy's total expenditure.

questions.question: GDP is equal to
options: the market value of all final goods and services produced within a country in a given period of time.
Y.
C + I + G + NX.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.question: An identity is an equation that
options: describes an equilibrium.
pertains to macroeconomics, not to microeconomics.
must be true because of how the variables in the equation are defined.
involves final goods, not intermediate goods.
questions.answer: must be true because of how the variables in the equation are defined.

questions.question: The consumption component of GDP includes spending on
options: durable goods and nondurable goods, but not spending on services.
durable goods and services, but not spending on nondurable goods.
nondurable goods and services, but not spending on durable goods.
durable goods, nondurable goods, and services.
questions.answer: durable goods, nondurable goods, and services.

questions.question: Consumption consists of spending by households on goods and services, with the exception of
options: purchases of intangible services.
purchases of durable goods.
purchases of new houses.
spending on education.
questions.answer: purchases of new houses.

questions.question: Which of the following is included in the consumption component of GDP?
options: household purchases of appliances.
household purchases of medical care.
household purchases of food.
All of the above are included in the consumption component of GDP.
questions.answer: All of the above are included in the consumption component of GDP.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a durable good?
options: a refrigerator
a quart of motor oil
a business suit
a can of soup
questions.answer: a refrigerator

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a durable good?
options: a refrigerator
an automobile
a business suit
a furnace
questions.answer: a business suit

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a nondurable good?
options: a loaf of bread
a pair of jeans
a microwave
a pound of bacon
questions.answer: a microwave

questions.question: When economists refer to intangible items, they are referring to such things as
options: illegal goods, and the value of such items is included in GDP.
illegal goods, and the value of such items is excluded from GDP.
hair styling and dental care, and the value of such items is included in GDP.
hair styling and dental care, and the value of such items is excluded from GDP.
questions.answer: hair styling and dental care, and the value of such items is included in GDP.

questions.question: Household spending on education is included in
options: consumption, although it might be argued that it would fit better in investment.
investment, although it might be argued that it would fit better in consumption.
government spending, based on the fact that most higher-education students attend publicly-supported colleges and universities.
None of the above is correct; in general, household spending on services is not included in any component of GDP.
questions.answer: consumption, although it might be argued that it would fit better in investment.

questions.question: Household spending on education is counted in which component or subcomponent of GDP?
options: consumption of durable goods
consumption of nondurable goods
consumption of services
investment
questions.answer: consumption of services

questions.question: Which of the following is included in the consumption component of U.S. GDP?
options: purchases of staplers, paper clips, and pens by U.S. business firms
purchases of natural gas by U.S. households
purchases of newly constructed homes by U.S. households
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: purchases of natural gas by U.S. households

questions.question: If you buy a burger and fries at your favorite fast food restaurant,
options: then neither GDP nor consumption will be affected because you would have eaten at home had you not bought the meal at the restaurant.
then GDP will be higher, but consumption spending will be unchanged.
then GDP will be unchanged, but consumption spending will be higher.
then both GDP and consumption spending will be higher.
questions.answer: then both GDP and consumption spending will be higher.

questions.question: John buys a used car for $5,400 and spends $600 on new parts, made in the U.S., to fix the car. The end result of these two transactions is
options: U.S. consumption purchases increase by $5,400 and U.S. GDP increases by $5,400.
U.S. consumption purchases increase by $6,000 and U.S. GDP increases by $6,000.
U.S. consumption purchases increase by $600 and U.S. GDP increases by $600.
U.S. consumption purchases increase by $600 and U.S. GDP increases by $6,000.
questions.answer: U.S. consumption purchases increase by $600 and U.S. GDP increases by $600.

questions.question: For the purpose of calculating GDP, investment is spending on
options: stocks, bonds, and other financial assets.
real estate and financial assets such as stocks and bonds.
capital equipment, inventories, and structures, including household purchases of new housing.
capital equipment, inventories, and structures, excluding household purchases of new housing.
questions.answer: capital equipment, inventories, and structures, including household purchases of new housing.

questions.question: What word do economists use to refer to the purchase of goods that will be used in the future to produce more goods and services?
options: capital
consumption
investment
costs
questions.answer: investment

questions.question: Which of the following is included in the investment component of GDP?
options: households' purchases of newly constructed homes
net additions to firms' inventories
firms' purchases of capital equipment
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.question: Which of the following examples of household spending is categorized as investment rather than consumption?
options: expenditures on durable goods such as automobiles and refrigerators
expenditures on intangibles items such as medical care
expenditures on new housing
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: expenditures on new housing

questions.question: Which of the following items is the one type of household expenditure that is categorized as investment rather than consumption?
options: spending on education
the purchase of stocks and bonds
the purchase of a new house
the purchase of durable goods such as stoves and washing machines
questions.answer: the purchase of a new house

questions.question: Which of the following is included in the investment component of GDP?
options: spending to build new houses
spending to build new factories
spending on business equipment such as welding equipment
All of the above are included in the investment component of GDP.
questions.answer: All of the above are included in the investment component of GDP.

questions.question: Which of the following is included in the investment component of GDP?
options: spending on new residential construction and spending on stocks and bonds
spending on new residential construction but not spending on stocks and bonds
spending on stocks and bonds but not spending on new residential construction
neither spending on stocks and bonds nor spending on new residential construction
questions.answer: spending on new residential construction but not spending on stocks and bonds

questions.question: Which of the following is included in the investment component of GDP?
options: spending on new business equipment such as power tools and spending on stocks and bonds
spending on new business equipment such as power tools but not spending on stocks and bonds
spending on stocks and bonds but not spending on new business equipment such as power tools
neither spending on new business equipment such as power tools nor spending on stocks and bonds
questions.answer: spending on new business equipment such as power tools but not spending on stocks and bonds

questions.question: The Carters' oldest son attends Big State University. He and his parents pay all his fees and tuition. These payments count in GDP as
options: investment.
government spending.
consumption of services.
consumption of durable goods.
questions.answer: consumption of services.

questions.question: Consider two items that might be included in GDP: (1) the estimated rental value of owner-occupied housing and (2) purchases of newly-constructed homes. How are these two items accounted for when GDP is calculated?
options: Both item (1) and item (2) are included in the consumption component of GDP.
Item (1) is included in the consumption component of GDP, while item (2) is included in the investment component of GDP.
Item (1) is included in the investment component of GDP, while item (2) is included in the consumption component of GDP.
Only item (2) is included in GDP, and it is included in the investment component.
questions.answer: Item (1) is included in the consumption component of GDP, while item (2) is included in the investment component of GDP.

questions.question: A U.S. publisher purchases new computers that were manufactured in the U.S. This purchase by itself makes
options: a positive contribution both to investment and to GDP.
a positive contribution both to consumption and to GDP.
a positive contribution to GDP, but it does not affect investment or consumption.
a positive contribution to investment, but it does not affect GDP.
questions.answer: a positive contribution both to investment and to GDP.

questions.question: A Minnesota farmer buys a new tractor made in Iowa by a German company. As a result,
options: U.S. investment and GDP increase, but German GDP is unaffected.
U.S. investment and German GDP increase, but U.S. GDP is unaffected.
U.S. investment, U.S. GDP, and German GDP are unaffected because tractors are intermediate goods.
U.S. investment, U.S. GDP, and German GDP all increase.
questions.answer: U.S. investment and GDP increase, but German GDP is unaffected.

questions.question: GA wind farm in Iowa buys a large turbine generator from a Swedish-owned factory located in Connecticut that uses workers who live in Connecticut. As a result,
options: U.S. investment, GDP, and GNP all increase by the same amount.
U.S. investment increases, but GDP and GNP are unaffected by the purchase.
U.S. investment and GDP increase by the same amount, but U.S. GNP increases by a smaller amount.
U.S. investment and GNP increase by the same amount, but U.S. GDP increases by a smaller amount.
questions.answer: U.S. investment and GDP increase by the same amount, but U.S. GNP increases by a smaller amount.

questions.question: The value of goods added to a firm's inventory in a certain year is treated as
options: consumption, since the goods will be sold to consumers in another period.
intermediate goods, and so is not included in that year's GDP.
investment, since GDP aims to measure the value of the economy's production that year.
spending on durable goods, since the goods could not be inventoried unless they were durable.
questions.answer: investment, since GDP aims to measure the value of the economy's production that year.

questions.question: Consumer goods that are produced, go into inventory, and are not sold during the current period are
options: counted as intermediate goods and so are not included in current period GDP.
counted in current period GDP only if the firm that produced them sells them to another firm.
included in current period GDP as inventory investment.
included in current period GDP as consumption.
questions.answer: included in current period GDP as inventory investment.

questions.question: During the current quarter, a firm produces consumer goods and adds some of those goods to its inventory rather than selling them. The value of the goods added to inventory is
options: not included in the current quarter GDP.
included in the current quarter GDP as investment.
included in the current quarter GDP as consumption.
included in the current quarter GDP as a statistical discrepancy.
questions.answer: included in the current quarter GDP as investment.

questions.question: During the third quarter of this year a firm produces consumer goods and adds some of those goods to its inventory. During the fourth quarter of this year, the firm sells the goods at a retail outlet, with the result that the value of its inventory at the end of the fourth quarter is smaller than the value of its inventory at the end of the third quarter. These actions affect which component(s) of fourthquarter GDP?
options: they increase consumption and have no affect on investment
they increase consumption and decrease investment
they have no affect on either consumption or investment
they have no affect on consumption and decrease investment
questions.answer: they increase consumption and decrease investment

questions.question: A movie company makes 500,000 DVDs of one of its latest releases. It sells 300,000 of them before the end of the second quarter, and holds the others in its warehouse. How will the 200,000 unsold DVDs be treated in the GDP statistics?
options: Since the DVDs eventually will be bought by consumers, they will be included as consumption in the second quarter.
Since the DVDs were not purchased in the second quarter, they will be counted as an increase in third-quarter GDP.
The DVDs will be counted as a change in inventory in the second quarter and so will be included in second-quarter GDP.
The DVDs will be counted as a change in inventory in the second quarter, and when sold in the third quarter will raise third-quarter GDP.
questions.answer: The DVDs will be counted as a change in inventory in the second quarter and so will be included in second-quarter GDP.

questions.question: The local Chevrolet dealership has an increase in inventory of 25 newly produced cars in 2006. In 2007, it sells all 25 cars. Which of the following statements is correct?
options: The value of the cars in inventory will be counted as part of 2006 GDP, and the value of the cars sold in 2007 will not increase 2007 GDP.
The value of the cars in inventory will not affect 2006 GDP, and the value of the cars sold in 2007 will increase 2007 GDP.
The value of the cars in inventory will be counted as part of 2006 GDP, and the value of the cars sold in 2007 will increase 2007 GDP.
The value of the cars in inventory will not affect 2006 GDP, and the value of the cars sold in 2007 will not increase 2007 GDP.
questions.answer: The value of the cars in inventory will be counted as part of 2006 GDP, and the value of the cars sold in 2007 will not increase 2007 GDP.

questions.question: A U.S. firm produces nail guns in the first quarter of 2010 and adds them to its inventory. In the second quarter of 2010 the firm sells the nail guns to a U.S. construction company. In which quarter(s) does(do) these transactions raise investment?
options: the first and the second
the first but not the second
the second but not the first
neither the first nor the second
questions.answer: the first but not the second

questions.question: A U.S. firm produces nail guns in the first quarter of 2010 and adds them to its inventory. In the second quarter of 2010 the firm sells the nail guns to a U.S. construction company. In which quarter(s) is (are) GDP higher?
options: the first and the second
the first but not the second
the second but not the first
neither the first nor the second
questions.answer: the first but not the second

questions.question: A U.S. firm produces sweatshirts in the first quarter of 2010 and adds them to its inventory. In the second quarter of 2010 the firm sells the sweatshirts to consumers. In which quarter(s) does(do) these transactions raise consumption?
options: the first and the second
the first but not the second
the second but not the first
neither the first nor the second
questions.answer: the second but not the first

questions.question: A good is produced by a firm in 2009, added to the firm's inventory in 2010, and sold to a household in 2010. As a result, on net,
options: 2009 GDP increased and 2010 GDP decreased.
2009 GDP decreased and 2010 GDP increased.
2009 GDP did not change and 2010 GDP increased.
2009 GDP increased and 2010 GDP did not change.
questions.answer: 2009 GDP increased and 2010 GDP did not change.

questions.question: A good is produced by a firm in 2010, added to the firm's inventory in 2010, and sold to a household in 2011. It follows that
options: the value of the good is added to the investment category of 2010 GDP, added to the consumption category of 2011 GDP, and subtracted from the investment category of 2011 GDP.
the value of the good is added to the investment category of 2010 GDP, added to the consumption category of 2011 GDP, and not included in the investment category of 2011 GDP.
the value of the good is added to the investment category of 2010 GDP, subtracted from the consumption category of 2011 GDP, and not included in the investment category of 2011 GDP.
the value of the good is added to the investment category of 2010 GDP, subtracted from the consumption category of 2011 GDP, and added to the investment category of 2011 GDP.
questions.answer: the value of the good is added to the investment category of 2010 GDP, added to the consumption category of 2011 GDP, and subtracted from the investment category of 2011 GDP.

questions.question: Rocket Energy Drink Company buys sugar to produce energy drinks. At the end of a quarter both its inventory of sugar and its inventory of energy drinks has increased. Investment for the quarter will include
options: both the increased inventory of sugar and the increased inventory of energy drinks.
the increased inventory of sugar, but not the increased inventory of energy drinks.
the increased inventory of energy drinks, but not the increased inventory of sugar.
neither the increased inventory of sugar nor the increased inventory of energy drinks.
questions.answer: both the increased inventory of sugar and the increased inventory of energy drinks.

questions.question: Which of the following items is included in GDP?
options: the sale of stocks and bonds
the sale of used goods
the sale of services such as those performed by a doctor
All of the above are included in GDP.
questions.answer: the sale of services such as those performed by a doctor

questions.question: Government purchases include spending on goods and services by
options: the federal government, but not by state or local governments.
federal and state governments, but not by local governments.
federal, state, and local governments.
federal, state, and local governments, as well as household spending by employees of those governments.
questions.answer: federal, state, and local governments.

questions.question: Which of the following items is counted as part of government purchases?
options: The federal government pays the salary of a Navy officer.
The state of Nevada pays a private firm to repair a Nevada state highway.
The city of Las Vegas, Nevada pays a private firm to collect garbage in that city.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.question: Recently, the U.S. national income accounts have switched to calling government purchases
options: government spending and transfer payments.
transfer payments and gross investment by government.
government consumption expenditure and gross investment.
government wages, salaries, and investment expenditure.
questions.answer: government consumption expenditure and gross investment.

questions.question: A form of government spending that is not made in exchange for a currently produced good or service is called
options: a transfer payment.
consumption.
investment.
None of the above is correct.
questions.answer: a transfer payment.

questions.question: A transfer payment is
options: a payment for moving expenses a worker receives when he or she is transferred by an employer to a new location.
a payment that is automatically transferred from your bank account to pay a bill or some other obligation.
a form of government spending that is not made in exchange for a currently produced good or service.
the benefit that a person receives from an expenditure by government minus the taxes that were collected by government to fund that expenditure.
questions.answer: a form of government spending that is not made in exchange for a currently produced good or service.

questions.question: Transfer payments
options: are payments that flow from government to households.
are not made in exchange for currently produced goods or services.
alter household income, but they do not reflect the economy's production.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.question: A transfer payment is a payment made by
options: consumers, but not in exchange for a tangible product.
firms, but not in exchange for capital equipment.
foreigners, but not in exchange for a domestically-produced good or service.
government, but not in exchange for a currently produced good or service.
questions.answer: government, but not in exchange for a currently produced good or service.

questions.question: Transfer payments are
options: included in GDP because they represent income to individuals.
included in GDP because they eventually will be spent on consumption.
not included in GDP because they are not payments for currently produced goods or services.
not included in GDP because taxes will have to be raised to pay for them.
questions.answer: not included in GDP because they are not payments for currently produced goods or services.

questions.question: Which of the following represents a transfer payment?
options: You transfer $1,000 from your bank account to a mutual fund.
The government sends your grandfather his Social Security check.
You make a payment to get legal documents showing you purchased a previously owned home.
Your employer automatically transfers $100 each month from your wages to a non-taxable medical spending account.
questions.answer: The government sends your grandfather his Social Security check.

questions.question: Social Security payments are
options: included in GDP because they represent current income.
included in GDP because they represent potential consumption.
excluded from GDP because they are not private pensions.
excluded from GDP because they do not reflect the economy's production.
questions.answer: excluded from GDP because they do not reflect the economy's production.

questions.question: Unemployment compensation is
options: part of GDP because it represents income.
part of GDP because the recipients must have worked in the past to qualify.
not part of GDP because it is a transfer payment.
not part of GDP because the payments reduce business profits.
questions.answer: not part of GDP because it is a transfer payment.

questions.question: To encourage formation of small businesses, the government could provide subsidies; these subsidies
options: would be included in GDP because they are part of government purchases.
would be included in GDP because they are part of investment expenditures.
would not be included in GDP because they are transfer payments.
would not be included in GDP because the government raises taxes to pay for them.
questions.answer: would not be included in GDP because they are transfer payments.

questions.question: After the terrorist attacks on September 11, 2001, governments within the United States raised expenditures to increase security at airports. These purchases of goods and services are
options: not included in GDP since they do not represent production.
not included in GDP since the government collects taxes to pay for them.
included in GDP since government expenditures on goods and services are included in GDP.
included in GDP only to the extent that the federal government, rather than state or local governments, paid for them.
questions.answer: included in GDP since government expenditures on goods and services are included in GDP.

questions.question: Which of the following items is counted as part of government purchases?
options: The federal government pays $2,000 in Social Security benefits to a retired person.
The city of Athens, Ohio pays $10,000 to a tree-trimming firm to trim trees along city boulevards.
The state of Nebraska pays $1,000 to help a low-income family pay its medical bills.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: The city of Athens, Ohio pays $10,000 to a tree-trimming firm to trim trees along city boulevards.

questions.question: If total spending rises from one year to the next, then
options: the economy must be producing a larger output of goods and services.
goods and services must be selling at higher prices.
either the economy must be producing a larger output of goods and services, or goods and services must be selling at higher prices, or both.
employment or productivity must be rising.
questions.answer: either the economy must be producing a larger output of goods and services, or goods and services must be selling at higher prices, or both.

questions.question: If total spending rises from one year to the next, then which of the following could not be true?
options: the economy is producing a smaller output of goods and services, and goods and services are selling at higher prices
the economy is producing a larger output of goods and services, and goods and services are selling at lower prices
the economy is producing a larger output of goods and services, and goods and services are selling at higher prices
the economy is producing a smaller output of goods and services, and goods and services are selling at lower prices
questions.answer: the economy is producing a smaller output of goods and services, and goods and services are selling at lower prices

questions.question: If the prices of all goods and services produced in the economy rose while the quantity of all goods and services stayed the same, which would rise?
options: both real GDP and nominal GDP
real GDP but not nominal GDP
nominal GDP but not real GDP
neither nominal GDP nor real GDP
questions.answer: nominal GDP but not real GDP

questions.question: When studying changes in the economy over time, economists want a measure of the total quantity of goods and services the economy is producing that is not affected by changes in the prices of those goods and services. In other words, economists want to study
options: nominal GDP.
real GDP.
the GDP deflator.
GNP.
questions.answer: real GDP.

questions.question: Changes in nominal GDP reflect
options: only changes in prices.
only changes in the amounts being produced.
both changes in prices and changes in the amounts being produced.
neither changes in prices nor changes in the amounts being produced.
questions.answer: both changes in prices and changes in the amounts being produced.

questions.question: Changes in real GDP reflect
options: only changes in prices.
only changes in the amounts being produced.
both changes in prices and changes in the amounts being produced.
neither changes in prices nor changes in the amounts being produced.
questions.answer: only changes in the amounts being produced.

questions.question: Real GDP is the yearly production of final goods and services valued at
options: current prices.
constant prices.
expected future prices.
the ratio of current prices to constant prices.
questions.answer: constant prices.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about GDP is correct?
options: Nominal GDP values production at current prices, whereas real GDP values production at constant prices.
Nominal GDP values production at constant prices, whereas real GDP values production at current prices.
Nominal GDP values production at market prices, whereas real GDP values production at the cost of the resources used in the production process.
Nominal GDP values production at the cost of the resources used in the production process, whereas real GDP values production at market prices..
questions.answer: Nominal GDP values production at current prices, whereas real GDP values production at constant prices.

questions.question: Which of the following is always measured in prices from a base-year?
options: both nominal and real GDP
nominal but not real GDP
real but not nominal GDP
neither nominal nor real GDP
questions.answer: real but not nominal GDP

questions.question: Which of the following always uses prices and quantities from the same period?
options: both nominal and real GDP
nominal GDP but not real GDP
real GDP but not nominal GDP
neither nominal or real GDP
questions.answer: nominal GDP but not real GDP

questions.question: Which of the following is correct?
options: Nominal GDP is always less than real GDP.
Nominal GDP is always greater than real GDP.
Nominal GDP equals real GDP in the base year.
Nominal GDP equals real GDP in all years but the base year.
questions.answer: Nominal GDP equals real GDP in the base year.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about nominal GDP and real GDP is correct?
options: Nominal GDP is a better gauge of economic well-being than real GDP.
Real GDP is a better gauge of economic well-being than nominal GDP.
Real GDP and nominal GDP are equally good measures of economic well-being.
Neither nominal nor real GDP provide a measure of economic well-being.
questions.answer: Real GDP is a better gauge of economic well-being than nominal GDP.

questions.question: When economists talk about growth in the economy, they measure that growth as the
options: absolute change in nominal GDP from one period to another.
percentage change in nominal GDP from one period to another.
absolute change in real GDP from one period to another.
percentage change in real GDP from one period to another.
questions.answer: percentage change in real GDP from one period to another.

questions.question: The GDP deflator is the ratio of
options: real GDP to nominal GDP multiplied by 100.
real GDP to the inflation rate multiplied by 100.
nominal GDP to real GDP multiplied by 100.
nominal GDP to the inflation rate multiplied by 100.
questions.answer: nominal GDP to real GDP multiplied by 100.

questions.question: Changes in the GDP deflator reflect
options: only changes in prices.
only changes in the amounts being produced.
both changes in prices and changes in the amounts being produced.
neither changes in prices nor changes in the amounts being produced.
questions.answer: only changes in prices.

questions.question: The GDP deflator for years subsequent to the base year measures the change in
options: nominal GDP from the base year that cannot be attributable to a change in real GDP.
real GDP from the base year that cannot be attributable to a change in nominal GDP.
nominal GDP from the base year that cannot be attributable to a change in prices.
real GDP from the base year that cannot be attributable to a change in prices.
questions.answer: nominal GDP from the base year that cannot be attributable to a change in real GDP.

The term economists use to describe a situation in which the economy's overall price level is rising is
options: growth.
inflation.
recession.
expansion.
questions.answer: inflation.

questions.question: The inflation rate is the
options: absolute change in real GDP from one period to another.
percentage change in real GDP from one period to another.
absolute change in the price level from one period to another.
percentage change in the price level from one period to another.
questions.answer: percentage change in the price level from one period to another.

questions.question: The percentage change in the price level from one period to another is called
options: the growth rate.
the inflation rate.
the GDP deflator.
the unemployment rate.
questions.answer: the inflation rate.

questions.answer: A
